qas.question: What elements had the power of benefit or harm in Roman religion?
What kind of intervention could be sought to avoid disasters?
What was expected when the divine intervention benefited the patron?
What act was decreed in times of crisis in Rome?
What was the point of public procession to the god's temples?

context: The same <a0_0>divine agencies<a0_0/> who caused disease or harm also had the power to avert it, and so might be placated in advance. <a1_0>Divine<a1_0/> consideration might be sought to avoid the inconvenient delays of a journey, or encounters with banditry, piracy and shipwreck, with due <a2_0>gratitude<a2_0/> to be rendered on safe arrival or return. In times of great crisis, the Senate could decree collective <a3_0>public rites<a3_0/>, in which Rome's citizens, including women and children, moved in procession from one temple to the next, <a4_0>supplicating the gods<a4_0/>.
